ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Sudden onset of unilateral high-frequency hearing loss and tinnitus, potentially unnoticed until tinnitus onset.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Central Auditory Nervous System Lesion
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Absent left contralateral acoustic reflex with present ipsilateral reflexes suggests intra-axial brainstem pathology, possibly related to history of hyponatremia.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vestibular Schwannoma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus are classic red flags, though the specific reflex pattern points more towards a brainstem lesion.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and configuration.
To evaluate word recognition and check for retrocochlear signs like rollover.
To evaluate the integrity of the reflex arc and screen for retrocochlear/brainstem pathology.
To determine the extent of high-frequency hearing loss beyond 8 kHz.
To characterize tinnitus pitch, loudness, and maskability.
To quantify the functional and emotional impact of tinnitus (THI, TFI).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial evaluation revealed a right unilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss steeply sloping at 6-8 kHz, with normal hearing in the left ear. Word recognition was excellent bilaterally. Acoustic reflexes demonstrated a specific abnormality: absent left contralateral reflexes with preserved ipsilateral reflexes, raising suspicion for a central/brainstem pathology.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal through 4 kHz, sloping to 50-55 dB HL at 6-8 kHz. Left ear: Normal limits. PTA Right 8 dB, Left 5 dB.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Excellent word recognition (100%) bilaterally; no rollover.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Absent left contralateral reflexes; right contralateral and bilateral ipsilateral reflexes present.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Follow-up focused on tinnitus characterization. Ultra-high frequency testing showed the right ear loss extended to 16 kHz before recovering. Tinnitus was matched to a low frequency (1000 Hz) despite the high-frequency loss. Questionnaires indicated mild distress.

tests.name: Ultra-high frequency audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear loss continues through 16 kHz, recovering at 18-20 kHz. Left ear normal 10-20 kHz.

tests.name: Tinnitus Evaluation
tests.result_summary: Pitch match 1000 Hz; Loudness match 10 dB SL; Minimum Masking Level 10 dB SL; No residual inhibition.

counseling_actions: Advise on 'mixing point' strategy for sound therapy (level just below complete masking)
Discuss the link between anxiety and tinnitus perception
Explain the importance of ABR or MRI to rule out retrocochlear pathology given asymmetric findings
Reassure regarding the non-emergency nature of tinnitus while emphasizing diagnostic follow-up

escalation.rationale_short: Referral for ABR or MRI is strongly recommended to rule out retrocochlear or brainstem pathology (e.g., acoustic neuroma, central lesion) due to asymmetric loss and reflex abnormalities.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor symptoms and re-evaluate need for intervention.

expected_outcome: Patient reported no change in tinnitus or hearing symptoms 6 months later.
Patient declined further testing or treatment after self-education alleviated anxiety.
